skill.name: astropy
skill.description: Comprehensive Python library for astronomy and astrophysics. This skill should be used when working with astronomical data including celestial coordinates, physical units, FITS files, cosmological calculations, time systems, tables, world coordinate systems (WCS), and astronomical data analysis. Use when tasks involve coordinate transformations, unit conversions, FITS file manipulation, cosmological distance calculations, time scale conversions, or astronomical data processing.

skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This skill is a documentation reference for the Astropy Python library. All 406 static findings are false positives. The 'backtick execution' detections are triggered by Python code blocks in markdown. The 'C2 keywords' are astronomy terms like 'distance' and 'separation'. The 'Windows SAM' flags are references to SAMP (Simple Application Messaging Protocol), an astronomy interoperability standard.

content.user_title: Analyze Astronomical Data with Astropy Python Library
content.value_statement: Working with astronomical data requires handling complex coordinate systems, file formats, and calculations. This skill provides guidance for using Astropy to process celestial coordinates, FITS files, and cosmological computations.
actual_capabilities: Guide coordinate transformations between ICRS, Galactic, FK5, and AltAz systems
Explain FITS file reading, writing, and header manipulation
Assist with cosmological distance and age calculations using standard models
Help with astronomical unit conversions and quantity handling
Support time scale conversions between UTC, TAI, TT, and TDB
Advise on table operations for astronomical catalogs
limitations: This skill provides guidance only and does not execute Python code directly
Requires astropy package to be installed in the user environment
Online queries like SkyCoord.from_name require internet connectivity
Large dataset processing performance depends on available system memory

use_cases.title: Convert Celestial Coordinates
use_cases.description: Transform coordinates between different reference frames for observation planning or catalog cross-matching.

use_cases.title: Process FITS Astronomy Files
use_cases.description: Read and analyze FITS format telescope images and catalogs for research or data pipeline development.

use_cases.title: Calculate Cosmological Distances
use_cases.description: Compute luminosity distances, lookback times, and Hubble parameters for distant galaxy analysis.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Coordinate Conversion
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I convert ICRS coordinates (RA=10.5 deg, Dec=41.2 deg) to Galactic coordinates using astropy?

prompt_templates.title: Read FITS File
prompt_templates.scenario: Extract data from a FITS image
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to open a FITS file, read the image data from the first extension, and access header keywords like EXPTIME.

prompt_templates.title: Cosmology Calculation
prompt_templates.scenario: Find distance to a high-redshift galaxy
prompt_templates.prompt: Calculate the luminosity distance and lookback time to a galaxy at redshift z=2.5 using the Planck18 cosmology.

prompt_templates.title: Catalog Cross-Matching
prompt_templates.prompt: I have two astronomical catalogs with RA/Dec columns. How do I cross-match them within 1 arcsecond using astropy coordinates?

output_examples.input: How do I convert a coordinate from ICRS to Galactic?
output: Create a SkyCoord object with your RA and Dec values in ICRS frame
Access the .galactic attribute to transform to Galactic coordinates
The result contains .l (longitude) and .b (latitude) in degrees

output_examples.input: What is the luminosity distance at redshift 1.5?
output: Using Planck18 cosmology, the luminosity distance at z=1.5 is approximately 11.1 Gpc
The angular diameter distance is about 1.78 Gpc
The lookback time is roughly 9.4 billion years

best_practices: Always attach units to quantities using astropy.units to prevent dimensional errors
Use context managers when opening FITS files to ensure proper resource cleanup
Process coordinate arrays rather than looping for better performance
anti_patterns: Do not hardcode unit conversions manually when astropy can handle them automatically
Avoid looping over individual coordinates when array operations are available
Do not assume coordinate frames match without explicit verification

faq.question: What is astropy used for?
faq.answer: Astropy is a Python library for astronomy providing tools for coordinates, units, FITS files, cosmology, time handling, and data tables.

faq.question: How do I install astropy?
faq.answer: Install with pip: 'pip install astropy' or with all optional dependencies: 'pip install astropy[all]'.

faq.question: What coordinate systems does astropy support?
faq.answer: Astropy supports ICRS, FK5, FK4, Galactic, AltAz, Ecliptic, Galactocentric, and many other astronomical reference frames.

faq.question: Can astropy read FITS files?
faq.answer: Yes, astropy.io.fits module provides full support for reading, writing, and manipulating FITS files including headers and data.

faq.question: What cosmological models are available?
faq.answer: Built-in models include Planck18, Planck15, WMAP9, WMAP7, and WMAP5. You can also create custom cosmological models.

faq.question: How do I handle time in astropy?
faq.answer: Use astropy.time.Time for precise time handling with support for UTC, TAI, TT, TDB scales and formats like JD, MJD, ISO.
